DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text description of the anatomic coverage within a Positron Electron Emission (PET) scan.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A subdivision of data or images obtained by gathering information with a positron emission tomography (PET) sensing device using a radioactive substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.:Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pictures of structures inside the body. Scans often used in diagnosing, staging, and monitoring disease include liver scans, bone scans, and computed tomography (CT) or computerized axial tomography (CAT) scans and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. In liver scanning and bone scanning, radioactive substances that are injected into the bloodstream collect in these organs. A scanner that detects the radiation is used to create pictures. In CT scanning, an x-ray machine linked to a computer is used to produce detailed pictures of organs inside the body. MRI scans use a large magnet connected to a computer to create pictures of areas inside the body.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: The data or image obtained by gathering information with a sensing device.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 9/8/10 released DEC as part of caDSR cleanup activity.  12/19/07 created for U of WASH FES, FMISO studies

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An electronic device that generates a digital representation of an image for data input to a computer._Relating to anatomy._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Regional; limited to a particular location or area.: Pictures of structures inside the body. Scans often used in diagnosing, staging, and monitoring disease include liver scans, bone scans, and computed tomography (CT) or computerized axial tomography (CAT) scans and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. In liver scanning and bone scanning, radioactive substances that are injected into the bloodstream collect in these organs. A scanner that detects the radiation is used to create pictures. In CT scanning, an x-ray machine linked to a computer is used to produce detailed pictures of organs inside the body. MRI scans use a large magnet connected to a computer to create pictures of areas inside the body.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a broader area or region of the body.
The data or image obtained by gathering information with a sensing device.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Whole; including all components without exception; being one unit or constituting the full amount or extent or duration; complete.: The entire physical structure of an organism.  It is composed of anatomic systems, regions, cavities, and spaces.: Pictures of structures inside the body. Scans often used in diagnosing, staging, and monitoring disease include liver scans, bone scans, and computed tomography (CT) or computerized axial tomography (CAT) scans and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. In liver scanning and bone scanning, radioactive substances that are injected into the bloodstream collect in these organs. A scanner that detects the radiation is used to create pictures. In CT scanning, an x-ray machine linked to a computer is used to produce detailed pictures of organs inside the body. MRI scans use a large magnet connected to a computer to create pictures of areas inside the body.

Concepts.definition: Including all components without exception; constituting the full amount or extent or duration; complete.
The entire physical structure of an organism. It is composed of anatomic systems, regions, cavities, and spaces.
The data or image obtained by gathering information with a sensing device.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of computer tomography whereby a contrast medium is administered intravenously or orally prior to X-ray imaging.

Concepts.definition: A type of computer tomography whereby a contrast medium is administered intravenously or orally prior to X-ray imaging.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: An electronic device that generates a digital representation of an image for data input to a computer.:Relating to anatomy.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: An electronic device that generates a digital representation of an image for data input to a computer or a receiver designed to search for a signal within a specified frequency range.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

DataElement.changeDescription: Created to support VCU adoption of C3D
